Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Screencast Integration with Scientific Probeware Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project is focused on helping students demonstrate critical thinking and reasoning skills for hands-on activities involving scientific probeware systems without requiring writing proficiency. A challenge facing educators is to ensure that instruction covers important content in a way that can reach all students. When teaching STEM concepts (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math), it is essential to provide opportunities to investigate questions about the world that students encounter in daily life in much the same way that scientists and mathematicians do; however, many students do not have the writing proficiency to express the complexity of their observations, become frustrated and lose interest in STEM subjects. This project is intended to increase the success rate at which students demonstrate, explain, and document their knowledge when working with probeware experiments. This project has the potential to help students to enjoy scientific experimentation and develop an interest in science strong motivators for pursuing opportunities in STEM careers. The success of this project will support the significant improvement of science and engineering education, and help the United States to increase the number of students who enter STEM fields to meet the rapidly expanding demand for scientists and engineers in the future.

This technology, when commercialized, will provide school districts a student-centered, curriculum-agnostic learning and assessment tool that incorporates an innovative screencasting tool. Its use will support students? analysis and mastery of complex STEM concepts and practices when participating in experiments using scientific probeware, without requiring writing proficiency. The goal of the research is to develop a portable software tool that enables real time student documentation and effective teacher assessment of students? probeware STEM activities. The resulting learning tool will function as a portable application housed on a flash drive, capture student explanations and demonstrations in real time, and allow playback operation on electronic devices with a display screen without the need for an Internet connection. This portability will provide support for students during probeware experiments, then allow them to revisit an entire lab experience in real or accelerated time within or away from school. The innovation will enable tangible documentation for the types of science skills and practices that embody the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS). Phase I research will focus on demonstrating the feasibility and functionality for a portable application that builds upon prior NSF-funded core technology, measure the impact of the innovation on elementary, middle, and high school students? knowledge integration, explanatory behaviors, and science practices, and demonstrate its feasibility for using the device in student assessment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Inquiry Technologies, LLC successfully proved feasibility for all technical development and research objectives associated with the SBIR Phase I study titled Screencast Integration with Scientific Probeware Systems. Through Phase I, our technology has been feasibly integrated into activities that take place in STEM classrooms using scientific data gathering hardware and software equipment, commonly referred to as probeware. The portable app software that was designed, developed, and tested during this Phase I grant (pHlash Lab) represented a significant enhancement that expanded upon a digital capture toolset that was initiated with previous NSF funding. We examined the extent to which our innovation supported students’ integration of science practices, knowledge acquisition, and communication skills associated with hands-on activities involving data gathering and analytical technology. A total of five investigations were conducted in five separate classroom settings ranging from first grade through high school. Each activity provided students with a description and background information associated with the project, detailed procedural sets, plus the means for collecting data, analyzing results, and drawing conclusions.

pHlash Lab’s impact on student learning and expression of their ideas through significant in all five investigations involved with the study. Every first grade student involved in the study was able to create a digital capture video that presented their results from the activity in a forum that exceeded their writing capacity. The ease-of-use in which the software operated provided opportunities for many of the pre-writers to express their understanding of science concepts in a highly efficient and manageable way. Working in collaborative groups, the third grade students that were involved with frictional forces were able to analyze and express their understanding for data that was collected by the probeware system and displayed in a graphical format. Significant modifications to the instructional sets were developed and implemented with our third investigation that involved high school physical science students. The students were able to make predictions in various formats, document those efforts using our digital capture technology, and use the playback feature to revisit their hypotheses after performing their motion activities. The groups involved in the motion lab were also successful in implementing peer review as they evaluated the visual components of motion graphs which were accompanied by spoken explanations from the participating students. The functionality of pHlash Lab enhanced the level of social interaction among the students involved in this activity. Findings from the high school chemical reaction lab indicated that when students used our innovation, they are far more likely to integrate evidence provided by graphs compared to when they are asked to provide written explanations for the same tasks. The increased amount of information and evidence used to support the students’ ideas when using our software, enabled teachers with greater opportunities to provide formative feedback to address specific misconceptions that may be held by the students. The investigation that involve middle school students in their exploration with power output generated by wind turbines, revealed that simply knowing in advance that an explanation involving the use of our technology will occur in a subsequent step of the activity appears to inspire students to the point where they evaluate their data to a much greater extent. That finding was further validated by three independent evaluations that occurred at various points in the investigation. In each of these instances, students in the treatment group made more references to the graphed data and they were better at applying that knowledge to their explanations. The students involved in this final investigation were challenged to think creatively and coming up with ways to improve the performance of the wind turbines they had been working with for two class periods. When students used our digital capture technology to present their ideas for performance enhancement, they not only came up with a greater number of ideas on average when compared to those that were writing out their suggestions on paper, but the ideas themselves were better supported by evidence and covered a broader realm of possibilities.

Findings from our observations, surveys, and interviews revealed that students and teachers overwhelmingly thought our technology was easy to use and had a very low learning curve associated with our technology. The implementation of our technology did not impede the teachers’ daily routines nor did it create any distractions with regard to content delivery. Our findings set the foundation to further our research and development efforts through a Phase II award. Those efforts will utilize what we have learned from this highly successful project, and that knowledge will be used to develop a system that can reach a much wider audience of students and teachers.
